documents: The Great Wall of China was built over many centuries by various Chinese dynasties. Construction began in the 7th century BC and continued through the Ming Dynasty. The wall stretches approximately 13,000 miles across northern China.
The Eiffel Tower was constructed for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. It stands 324 meters tall and was designed by Gustave Eiffel. The tower receives millions of visitors each year.
Mount Everest is the world's highest mountain peak. It is located in the Himalayas on the border between Nepal and Tibet. Many climbers attempt to reach its summit each year.
The Amazon rainforest covers approximately 2.1 million square miles. It spans across nine countries in South America. The rainforest is home to countless species of plants and animals.
The Sahara Desert is the largest hot desert in the world. It covers much of North Africa and is roughly the size of the United States. Temperatures can exceed 120 degrees Fahrenheit during the day.
The Pacific Ocean is the largest ocean on Earth. It covers about one-third of the planet's surface. The ocean contains thousands of islands and diverse marine ecosystems.
Antarctica is the coldest continent on Earth. It contains about 90% of the world's ice. The continent has no permanent human residents.
The Nile River is often considered the longest river in the world. It flows through eleven countries in Africa. The river has been crucial for agriculture in Egypt for thousands of years.
Tokyo is the capital city of Japan. It has a population of over 13 million people. The city is known for its advanced technology and rich cultural heritage.
The Grand Canyon was formed by the Colorado River over millions of years. It is located in Arizona and attracts millions of tourists annually. The canyon is approximately 277 miles long.
Machu Picchu is an ancient Incan city located in Peru. It was built in the 15th century and later abandoned. The site was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911.
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States. It was dedicated in 1886 and stands on Liberty Island. The statue symbolizes freedom and democracy.
The Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest coral reef system. It is located off the coast of Australia. The reef is home to thousands of marine species.
Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument in England. It consists of large standing stones arranged in a circle. The purpose of the monument remains a mystery to archaeologists.
The Colosseum in Rome was built in the first century AD. It could hold up to 80,000 spectators for gladiatorial contests. The structure is now a popular tourist destination.

Niagara Falls consists of three waterfalls on the border between the US and Canada. The falls are a popular tourist attraction and source of hydroelectric power. Millions of gallons of water flow over the falls every minute.

The Taj Mahal was built in India as a mausoleum for Emperor Shah Jahan's wife. Construction was completed in 1653 after 22 years of work. The building is considered one of the finest examples of Mughal architecture.

Yellowstone National Park was the first national park in the United States. It was established in 1872 and spans three states. The park is famous for its geothermal features including Old Faithful geyser.

The Sydney Opera House is an iconic performing arts venue in Australia. It was designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon and opened in 1973. The building's distinctive shell design makes it instantly recognizable.
The Dead Sea is a salt lake located between Israel and Jordan. It is one of the saltiest bodies of water in the world. The high salt content allows people to float effortlessly on its surface.
question: How long is the Great Wall of China?

documents: William Shakespeare was born in Stratford-upon-Avon in 1564. He wrote 39 plays and 154 sonnets during his career. Shakespeare is widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language.
Leonardo da Vinci was an Italian Renaissance polymath. He was a painter, inventor, scientist, and engineer. His most famous works include the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper.
Albert Einstein developed the theory of relativity. He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921. Einstein's work revolutionized our understanding of space, time, and gravity.
Marie Curie was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize. She discovered the elements polonium and radium. Curie won Nobel Prizes in both Physics and Chemistry.
Charles Darwin proposed the theory of evolution by natural selection. He published 'On the Origin of Species' in 1859. Darwin's theory fundamentally changed biology and our understanding of life.
Vincent van Gogh was a Dutch post-impressionist painter. He created over 2,000 artworks during his career. Van Gogh's work became famous only after his death.
Nikola Tesla was a Serbian-American inventor and engineer. He developed the alternating current electrical system. Tesla held over 300 patents for his inventions.
Galileo Galilei was an Italian astronomer and physicist. He improved the telescope and made important astronomical observations. Galileo supported the heliocentric model of the solar system.
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart was an Austrian composer. He composed over 600 works during his short life. Mozart is considered one of the greatest classical composers of all time.
Pablo Picasso was a Spanish painter and sculptor. He co-founded the Cubist movement in art. Picasso's work spans many different periods and styles.
Isaac Newton formulated the laws of motion and universal gravitation. He also made significant contributions to mathematics and optics. Newton's work laid the foundation for classical mechanics.
Michelangelo was an Italian Renaissance artist. He painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel and sculpted David. Michelangelo was also an accomplished architect and poet.
Benjamin Franklin was an American polymath and founding father. He was a writer, scientist, inventor, and diplomat. Franklin helped draft the Declaration of Independence.
Johann Sebastian Bach was a German Baroque composer. He wrote over 1,000 musical compositions including cantatas and fugues. Bach's work greatly influenced Western classical music.
Frida Kahlo was a Mexican artist known for her self-portraits. She painted about 200 works during her career. Kahlo's art often depicted pain and passion from her personal experiences.
Thomas Edison was an American inventor and businessman. He held over 1,000 patents for his inventions. Edison developed the practical incandescent light bulb and phonograph.
Jane Austen was an English novelist of the Romantic period. She wrote six major novels including Pride and Prejudice. Austen's works critique the British landed gentry of her time.

Stephen Hawking was a British theoretical physicist and cosmologist. He made groundbreaking discoveries about black holes and the nature of the universe. Hawking wrote several popular science books including 'A Brief History of Time'.
Edgar Allan Poe was an American writer and poet. He is known for his tales of mystery and the macabre. Poe is credited with inventing the detective fiction genre.
Andy Warhol was an American artist and leader of the pop art movement. He created iconic works featuring Campbell's soup cans and celebrities. Warhol's art challenged traditional notions of fine art.
question: How many plays did Shakespeare write?

documents: Photosynthesis is the process by which plants convert light energy into chemical energy. It occurs primarily in the chloroplasts of plant cells. The process produces glucose and oxygen from carbon dioxide and water.

DNA is the hereditary material in most living organisms. It consists of two complementary strands forming a double helix. DNA contains the genetic instructions for the development and function of all living things.
The water cycle describes the continuous movement of water on Earth. It includes evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and collection. This cycle is driven by solar energy and gravity.
Cellular respiration is the process cells use to break down glucose for energy. It occurs in the mitochondria of eukaryotic cells. The process produces ATP, carbon dioxide, and water.

Evolution is the change in heritable traits of biological populations over time. It occurs through mechanisms like natural selection and genetic drift. Evolution explains the diversity of life on Earth.

Ecosystems are communities of living organisms interacting with their physical environment. They include producers, consumers, and decomposers. Energy flows through ecosystems in food chains and webs.

Genetics is the study of heredity and variation in living organisms. Genes are the basic units of heredity passed from parents to offspring. Genetic variation contributes to the diversity within species.

The greenhouse effect is a natural process that warms Earth's surface. Greenhouse gases in the atmosphere trap heat from the sun. Human activities have intensified this effect, leading to climate change.

Plate tectonics explains the movement of Earth's lithospheric plates. These plates float on the semi-fluid asthenosphere below. Plate movement causes earthquakes, volcanic activity, and mountain formation.

Osmosis is the movement of water across a semipermeable membrane. Water moves from areas of lower solute concentration to higher concentration. This process is crucial for maintaining cell volume and shape.
Biodiversity refers to the variety of life on Earth at all levels. It includes genetic, species, and ecosystem diversity. Biodiversity is essential for ecosystem stability and human well-being.
Food webs show the feeding relationships between organisms in an ecosystem. They consist of interconnected food chains. Energy and nutrients flow through these complex networks.

Natural selection is the mechanism by which organisms with favorable traits survive and reproduce. It leads to evolutionary changes in populations over time. Darwin first described this process in detail.
Symbiosis describes close relationships between different species. Types include mutualism, commensalism, and parasitism. These relationships can benefit one or both organisms involved.
The carbon cycle describes the movement of carbon through Earth's systems. It includes processes in the atmosphere, oceans, and biosphere. Human activities are altering the natural carbon cycle.

Homeostasis is the maintenance of stable internal conditions in living organisms. It involves feedback mechanisms that regulate temperature, pH, and other variables. Homeostasis is essential for proper cellular function.

Adaptation refers to traits that help organisms survive in their environment. Adaptations can be structural, behavioral, or physiological. They develop through the process of natural selection over generations.

The nitrogen cycle involves the conversion of nitrogen between its various chemical forms. Bacteria play key roles in nitrogen fixation and decomposition. This cycle is essential for protein synthesis in living organisms.

Succession is the predictable change in species composition over time in an ecosystem. Primary succession occurs on bare rock or soil. Secondary succession happens after disturbances in established ecosystems.
Mutations are changes in DNA sequences that can affect organism traits. They can be caused by environmental factors or occur spontaneously. Mutations provide the raw material for evolution.
question: What does photosynthesis produce?

documents: The French Revolution began in 1789 and lasted until 1799. It was sparked by financial crisis, social inequality, and Enlightenment ideas. The revolution led to the end of the monarchy and the rise of Napoleon.
World War II lasted from 1939 to 1945. It involved most of the world's nations and resulted in millions of casualties. The war ended with the defeat of Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan.

The Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the late 18th century. It transformed manufacturing from hand production to mechanized factory production. This period saw the development of steam power and new transportation systems.

The American Civil War was fought from 1861 to 1865. It was primarily caused by disagreements over slavery and states' rights. The war resulted in the abolition of slavery and preservation of the Union.

The Renaissance was a period of cultural rebirth in Europe from the 14th to 17th centuries. It saw renewed interest in classical learning and the arts. Famous figures include Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo.

The Cold War was a period of geopolitical tension between the United States and Soviet Union. It lasted from roughly 1947 to 1991 without direct military conflict. The period was characterized by nuclear arms races and proxy wars.

The Roman Empire existed from 27 BC to 476 AD in the West. It was one of the largest empires in ancient history. The empire fell due to various factors including barbarian invasions and internal instability.

The Great Depression was a severe economic downturn that began in 1929. It lasted throughout the 1930s and affected countries worldwide. Unemployment rates reached 25% in the United States during this period.
The Age of Exploration occurred from the 15th to 17th centuries. European explorers discovered new trade routes and continents. This period led to increased global trade and colonization.

The Protestant Reformation began in the 16th century with Martin Luther's 95 Theses. It challenged the authority of the Catholic Church. The movement led to the formation of various Protestant denominations.

Ancient Egypt was a civilization that flourished along the Nile River. It lasted for over 3,000 years and is known for its pyramids and pharaohs. Egyptian culture greatly influenced the ancient world.
The Mongol Empire was the largest contiguous land empire in history. It was founded by Genghis Khan in the 13th century. The empire stretched from Eastern Europe to the Pacific Ocean.

The Enlightenment was an intellectual movement in 17th and 18th century Europe. It emphasized reason, science, and individual rights. Enlightenment ideas influenced the American and French Revolutions.

The Byzantine Empire was the continuation of the Roman Empire in the East. It lasted from 330 to 1453 AD with Constantinople as its capital. The empire preserved Greek and Roman culture through the Middle Ages.

The Crusades were a series of religious wars from 1095 to 1291. They were fought between Christians and Muslims for control of the Holy Land. The Crusades had lasting effects on European and Middle Eastern societies.
The Scientific Revolution occurred from the 16th to 18th centuries. It fundamentally changed views about the natural world. Key figures included Copernicus, Galileo, and Newton.
The Viking Age lasted from roughly 793 to 1066 AD. Vikings were seafaring Norse people who raided and traded across Europe. They established settlements in Iceland, Greenland, and North America.
The Silk Road was an ancient network of trade routes. It connected East and West from the 2nd century BC to the 14th century AD. The routes facilitated trade in silk, spices, and other goods.
The Meiji Restoration occurred in Japan in 1868. It restored imperial rule and ended the feudal system. This period saw rapid modernization and westernization of Japan.

The Space Race was a competition between the US and Soviet Union. It lasted from the 1950s to the 1970s and focused on spaceflight capability. The race culminated with the American moon landing in 1969.
question: When did the French Revolution begin?

documents: Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system. It has a mass greater than all other planets combined. Jupiter has over 80 known moons including the four Galilean moons.
The sun is a yellow dwarf star located at the center of our solar system. It accounts for 99.86% of the system's mass. The sun's energy comes from nuclear fusion reactions in its core.

Black holes are regions of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape. They form when massive stars collapse at the end of their lives. The event horizon marks the point of no return around a black hole.
The Milky Way is a spiral galaxy containing our solar system. It has an estimated 100-400 billion stars. The galaxy is approximately 100,000 light-years in diameter.
Mars is known as the Red Planet due to iron oxide on its surface. It has two small moons named Phobos and Deimos. Scientists are actively searching for signs of past or present life on Mars.

Neutron stars are incredibly dense remnants of supernova explosions. They contain more mass than the sun in a sphere only 20 kilometers across. A teaspoon of neutron star material would weigh about 6 billion tons.
Saturn is famous for its prominent ring system made of ice and rock particles. It is the second-largest planet in our solar system. Saturn has 146 known moons including Titan and Enceladus.

The Big Bang theory explains the origin and evolution of the universe. It suggests the universe began from an extremely hot and dense state about 13.8 billion years ago. The theory is supported by cosmic microwave background radiation.
Venus is the hottest planet in our solar system due to its thick atmosphere. Surface temperatures can reach 900 degrees Fahrenheit. Venus rotates backwards compared to most other planets.

Galaxies are massive collections of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter. There are estimated to be over 2 trillion galaxies in the observable universe. Galaxies come in spiral, elliptical, and irregular shapes.
Supernovas are explosive deaths of massive stars. They can briefly outshine entire galaxies and create heavy elements. Type Ia supernovas are used as standard candles to measure cosmic distances.
The asteroid belt is a region between Mars and Jupiter containing numerous rocky objects. Most asteroids in our solar system are found here. Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt.
Exoplanets are planets that orbit stars other than our sun. Thousands have been discovered using various detection methods. Some exoplanets may have conditions suitable for life.

Dark matter makes up about 27% of the universe but doesn't interact with light. Its existence is inferred from gravitational effects on visible matter. Scientists are still trying to determine what dark matter actually is.
Comets are icy bodies that develop tails when approaching the sun. They originate from the outer regions of the solar system. Halley's Comet is the most famous comet visible from Earth.

The International Space Station orbits Earth at an altitude of about 400 kilometers. It has been continuously occupied since November 2000. The station serves as a laboratory for scientific research in microgravity.
Mercury is the smallest planet in our solar system and closest to the sun. It has extreme temperature variations between day and night. Mercury has no atmosphere and no moons.
Red giant stars are evolved stars that have exhausted hydrogen in their cores. They expand dramatically and become much brighter. Our sun will eventually become a red giant in about 5 billion years.
The Hubble Space Telescope has been observing the universe since 1990. It has made numerous groundbreaking discoveries about space. Hubble orbits Earth every 97 minutes at 17,000 miles per hour.
Pulsars are rapidly rotating neutron stars that emit beams of radiation. They act like cosmic lighthouses sweeping radiation across space. Pulsars can rotate hundreds of times per second.
question: Which planet is the largest in our solar system?

documents: The human brain contains approximately 86 billion neurons. These neurons communicate through electrical and chemical signals. The brain weighs about 3 pounds and uses 20% of the body's energy.
The heart is a muscular organ that pumps blood throughout the body. It beats approximately 100,000 times per day. The heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles.
The liver is the largest internal organ in the human body. It performs over 500 different functions including detoxification. The liver can regenerate itself if part of it is removed.
Bones provide structure and support for the human body. The adult skeleton contains 206 bones. Bones also produce blood cells in the bone marrow.
The lungs are responsible for gas exchange in the respiratory system. They contain millions of tiny air sacs called alveoli. Humans breathe about 20,000 times per day.
The kidneys filter waste products from the blood. Each kidney contains about one million nephrons. The kidneys produce urine to eliminate toxins from the body.
Muscles make up about 40% of total body weight. There are three types: skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle. Muscles contract to produce movement and maintain posture.
The digestive system breaks down food into nutrients the body can use. It includes organs like the stomach, intestines, and pancreas. Digestion begins in the mouth with saliva.
The skin is the largest organ of the human body. It serves as a protective barrier against pathogens and UV radiation. Skin helps regulate body temperature through sweating.
Blood carries oxygen, nutrients, and waste products throughout the body. It consists of red cells, white cells, platelets, and plasma. The average adult has about 5 liters of blood.
The nervous system controls and coordinates body functions. It includes the brain, spinal cord, and peripheral nerves. Nerve impulses travel at speeds up to 120 meters per second.
The endocrine system produces hormones that regulate body processes. Key glands include the thyroid, adrenals, and pancreas. Hormones travel through the bloodstream to target organs.
The immune system defends the body against diseases and infections. It includes white blood cells, antibodies, and lymphatic organs. The immune system has both innate and adaptive responses.
The skeletal system provides structure and protects internal organs. It includes bones, cartilage, and ligaments. Bones store minerals like calcium and phosphorus.
The circulatory system transports blood throughout the body. It includes the heart, blood vessels, and blood. The system delivers oxygen and nutrients to cells.
The reproductive system enables humans to produce offspring. It differs between males and females but both produce gametes. Hormones regulate reproductive functions.
The urinary system removes waste products from the body. It includes the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra. This system also helps maintain fluid and electrolyte balance.
The lymphatic system helps maintain fluid balance and immune function. It includes lymph nodes, vessels, and organs like the spleen. Lymph fluid carries white blood cells throughout the body.
Hair and nails are made of a protein called keratin. They grow continuously throughout life. Hair helps regulate body temperature and protect the scalp.
The eyes are complex organs that detect light and create vision. They contain specialized cells called rods and cones. The brain processes visual information from both eyes.
question: How many neurons does the human brain contain?

documents: The cheetah is the fastest land animal, capable of reaching speeds up to 70 mph. It has a slender build and distinctive spotted coat. Cheetahs primarily hunt gazelles and other small antelopes in Africa.
Lions are known as the king of the jungle despite living in grasslands. They live in social groups called prides. Male lions have distinctive manes that darken with age.
Elephants are the largest land mammals on Earth. They have excellent memories and complex social structures. Elephants use their trunks for breathing, drinking, and grasping objects.
Polar bears are the largest carnivorous land mammals. They are excellent swimmers and primarily hunt seals. Polar bears have black skin underneath their white fur.
Giraffes are the tallest mammals in the world. Their long necks help them reach leaves high in trees. A giraffe's tongue can be up to 20 inches long.
Dolphins are highly intelligent marine mammals. They communicate through clicks, whistles, and body language. Dolphins live in social groups called pods.
Kangaroos are marsupials native to Australia. They move by hopping on their powerful hind legs. Female kangaroos carry their young in pouches.
Penguins are flightless birds adapted for life in water. They have waterproof feathers and streamlined bodies. Most penguin species live in the Southern Hemisphere.
Koalas are marsupials that primarily eat eucalyptus leaves. They sleep 18-22 hours per day to conserve energy. Koalas are found only in Australia.
Tigers are the largest wild cats in the world. Each tiger has a unique stripe pattern like human fingerprints. Tigers are solitary hunters and excellent swimmers.
Whales are the largest animals on Earth. Blue whales can grow up to 100 feet long. They communicate through complex songs that can travel for miles underwater.
Gorillas are the largest primates and share 98% of human DNA. They live in family groups led by a dominant silverback male. Gorillas are primarily herbivorous despite their size.

Pandas are bears known for their distinctive black and white coloring. They primarily eat bamboo and spend most of their time eating. Giant pandas are endangered with fewer than 2,000 remaining in the wild.
Octopuses are intelligent invertebrates with eight arms. They can change color and texture to camouflage themselves. Octopuses have three hearts and blue blood.
Hummingbirds are the smallest birds and can hover in mid-air. They beat their wings up to 80 times per second. Hummingbirds must eat every 10-15 minutes to maintain their energy.
Sharks have existed for over 400 million years. They have cartilaginous skeletons instead of bones. Great white sharks can detect blood from miles away.
Owls are nocturnal birds of prey with excellent night vision. Their feathers allow for silent flight while hunting. Owls can rotate their heads up to 270 degrees.
Bees are essential pollinators that help plants reproduce. A single bee colony can contain up to 80,000 bees. Bees communicate through dance to share information about food sources.
Butterflies undergo complete metamorphosis from caterpillar to adult. They taste with their feet and smell with their antennae. Some butterfly species migrate thousands of miles.
Wolves are social predators that hunt in packs. They have complex communication systems including howling. Wolves are the ancestors of domestic dogs.
question: What is the fastest land animal?

documents: Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius or 212 degrees Fahrenheit at sea level. The boiling point decreases at higher altitudes due to lower air pressure. Water is essential for all known forms of life.
Gold is a precious metal with the chemical symbol Au. It is highly resistant to corrosion and tarnishing. Gold has been used as currency and jewelry for thousands of years.
Diamond is the hardest naturally occurring substance on Earth. It forms deep within the Earth under extreme pressure and temperature. Diamonds are composed entirely of carbon atoms.
Iron is the most common element on Earth by mass. It rusts when exposed to oxygen and moisture. Iron is essential for making steel and is found in hemoglobin.
Helium is the second most abundant element in the universe. It is lighter than air and makes voices sound higher when inhaled. Helium is used in balloons and as a coolant.
Carbon is the basis of all organic compounds. It can form chains and rings with other carbon atoms. Carbon exists in several forms including diamond and graphite.
Oxygen makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere. It is essential for combustion and cellular respiration. Oxygen was first discovered by Joseph Priestley in 1774.
Nitrogen comprises about 78% of Earth's atmosphere. It is relatively inert under normal conditions. Nitrogen is essential for protein synthesis in living organisms.
Hydrogen is the most abundant element in the universe. It has one proton and one electron in its simplest form. Hydrogen is used in fuel cells and rocket fuel.
Silver is a precious metal known for its high electrical conductivity. It has antimicrobial properties and is used in medicine. Silver tarnishes when exposed to sulfur compounds.
Copper is an excellent conductor of electricity and heat. It develops a green patina when exposed to air over time. Copper is essential for many biological processes.
Lead is a heavy metal that is toxic to humans. It was once commonly used in paint and gasoline. Lead exposure can cause serious health problems, especially in children.
Mercury is the only metal that is liquid at room temperature. It is highly toxic and can cause neurological damage. Mercury is used in some thermometers and fluorescent lights.
Aluminum is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust. It is lightweight and resistant to corrosion. Aluminum is widely used in packaging and transportation.
Titanium is known for its high strength-to-weight ratio. It is biocompatible and used in medical implants. Titanium is also used in aerospace applications.
Platinum is a rare and valuable precious metal. It is used in catalytic converters and jewelry. Platinum is more valuable than gold in many markets.
Uranium is a radioactive element used in nuclear power. It naturally occurs in rocks and soil worldwide. Enriched uranium can be used to make nuclear weapons.
Sodium is a highly reactive alkali metal. It reacts violently with water to produce hydrogen gas. Sodium compounds like salt are essential for life.
Calcium is essential for bone and tooth formation. It is the most abundant mineral in the human body. Calcium also plays a role in muscle contraction and nerve function.
Magnesium is involved in over 300 enzyme reactions in the body. It is essential for energy production and protein synthesis. Magnesium deficiency can cause muscle cramps and fatigue.
question: At what temperature does water boil at sea level?

documents: The piano has 88 keys consisting of 52 white keys and 36 black keys. It was invented around 1700 by Bartolomeo Cristofori in Italy. The piano can play both melody and harmony simultaneously.
The violin is a string instrument played with a bow. It has four strings tuned in perfect fifths. The violin is the smallest and highest-pitched member of the violin family.
The guitar typically has six strings and is played by plucking or strumming. It originated in Spain and has become popular in many musical genres. Guitars can be acoustic or electric.
The drums are percussion instruments that produce sound when struck. A typical drum kit includes snare, bass, and tom drums plus cymbals. Drums provide rhythm and beat in most musical styles.
The trumpet is a brass instrument with a bright, penetrating sound. It has three valves that change the pitch. Trumpets are commonly used in orchestras, jazz bands, and marching bands.

The flute is a woodwind instrument that produces sound by blowing air across an opening. Modern flutes are typically made of metal despite being classified as woodwinds. The flute has a range of about three octaves.
The saxophone was invented by Adolphe Sax in the 1840s. It combines features of brass and woodwind instruments. Saxophones are commonly used in jazz, classical, and popular music.

The cello is a string instrument played while seated with the instrument between the knees. It is larger than a violin and has a deeper, richer tone. The cello is tuned in perfect fifths like the violin.
The clarinet is a single-reed woodwind instrument. It has a wide range spanning over three octaves. Clarinets are used in orchestras, concert bands, and jazz ensembles.

The French horn is a brass instrument with a distinctive coiled shape. It produces a warm, mellow tone and is notoriously difficult to play. French horns are essential members of orchestras and wind ensembles.
The tuba is the largest and lowest-pitched brass instrument. It provides the bass foundation in bands and orchestras. Despite its size, the tuba can be surprisingly agile and expressive.
The harp is a string instrument with strings of varying lengths. It is played by plucking the strings with fingers. Harps have been used in music for thousands of years across many cultures.

The oboe is a double-reed woodwind instrument with a distinctive nasal tone. It is often used to tune orchestras because of its stable pitch. The oboe requires significant breath control to play properly.
The trombone is a brass instrument that uses a slide to change pitch. It is the only orchestral instrument that can play true glissandos. Trombones come in several sizes with tenor being most common.
The bassoon is a large double-reed woodwind instrument. It provides bass and tenor voices in wind ensembles and orchestras. The bassoon is known for its distinctive appearance and rich, woody tone.

The xylophone is a percussion instrument with wooden bars arranged like a piano keyboard. It is played with mallets and produces bright, percussive tones. Xylophones are used in orchestras and marching bands.

The organ is a keyboard instrument that produces sound by forcing air through pipes. Church organs can have thousands of pipes and multiple keyboards. The organ is one of the oldest keyboard instruments.
The banjo is a string instrument with a drum-like body. It typically has four or five strings and is played with fingerpicks. Banjos are commonly associated with folk, country, and bluegrass music.
The harmonica is a small wind instrument played by blowing and drawing air. It uses free reeds to produce different pitches. Harmonicas are portable and popular in blues, folk, and country music.
The accordion is a box-shaped instrument with bellows and keys or buttons. It produces sound by forcing air through reeds. Accordions are popular in folk music traditions worldwide.
question: How many keys does a piano have?

documents: The United States consists of 50 states plus the District of Columbia. Alaska and Hawaii were the last states to join the union in 1959. The capital city is Washington, D.C.
China is the most populous country in the world with over 1.4 billion people. It has 34 province-level administrative divisions. Beijing is the capital and political center of China.
Russia is the largest country in the world by land area. It spans eleven time zones and borders sixteen other countries. Moscow is the capital and largest city of Russia.
Canada is the second-largest country by total area. It has ten provinces and three territories. Ottawa is the capital city, while Toronto is the most populous city.
Brazil is the largest country in South America. It shares borders with every South American country except Chile and Ecuador. Brasília is the capital, while São Paulo is the largest city.
India is the seventh-largest country by land area and second most populous. It has 28 states and 8 union territories. New Delhi is the capital and seat of government.
Australia is both a country and a continent. It consists of six states and two territories. Canberra is the capital, though Sydney is the largest city.
Germany is located in Central Europe and has sixteen federal states. It is the most populous member state of the European Union. Berlin is both the capital and largest city.
France is known for its rich history, culture, and cuisine. It is divided into 18 administrative regions. Paris is the capital and most visited city in the world.
Japan is an island nation in East Asia consisting of four main islands. It has 47 prefectures and a constitutional monarchy system. Tokyo is the capital and largest metropolitan area.
United Kingdom consists of England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. It is a constitutional monarchy with London as its capital. The UK has a parliamentary system of government.
Italy is a peninsula in Southern Europe shaped like a boot. It has twenty regions and is known for its art, history, and cuisine. Rome is the capital and largest city.
Mexico borders the United States to the north and has 31 states plus a federal district. It is the most populous Spanish-speaking country. Mexico City is the capital and largest city.
South Africa is located at the southern tip of Africa. It has nine provinces and eleven official languages. Cape Town is the legislative capital, while Pretoria is the executive capital.
Egypt is located in Northeast Africa and is famous for its ancient civilization. It has 27 governorates and is mostly desert. Cairo is the capital and largest city.
Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa with over 200 million people. It has 36 states and is divided into six geopolitical zones. Abuja is the capital city.
Argentina is the second-largest country in South America. It has 23 provinces and one autonomous city. Buenos Aires is the capital and largest city.
Turkey straddles both Europe and Asia and has 81 provinces. It has a rich history spanning ancient civilizations. Ankara is the capital, while Istanbul is the largest city.
Iran is located in Western Asia and has 31 provinces. It has one of the world's oldest major civilizations. Tehran is the capital and most populous city.
Thailand is located in Southeast Asia and has 77 provinces. It is known as the Land of Smiles. Bangkok is the capital and most populous city.
question: How many states does the United States have?

documents: The Mona Lisa was painted by Leonardo da Vinci between 1503 and 1519. It is housed in the Louvre Museum in Paris, France. The painting is famous for the subject's enigmatic smile and mysterious expression.
The Starry Night was painted by Vincent van Gogh in 1889. It depicts a swirling night sky over a village. The painting is one of van Gogh's most recognizable works.
Guernica was created by Pablo Picasso in 1937. It depicts the horrors of war and bombing of Guernica during the Spanish Civil War. The painting is rendered in black, white, and gray.
The Great Wave off Kanagawa was created by Japanese artist Hokusai around 1831. It is a woodblock print showing a large wave threatening boats. The image has become an icon of Japanese art.
American Gothic was painted by Grant Wood in 1930. It shows a farmer and his daughter standing in front of a Gothic Revival style house. The painting has become an American cultural icon.
The Scream was created by Edvard Munch in 1893. It depicts a figure on a bridge screaming against a turbulent orange sky. The painting represents anxiety and existential angst.
Girl with a Pearl Earring was painted by Johannes Vermeer around 1665. It shows a girl wearing an exotic dress and large pearl earring. The painting is often called the 'Mona Lisa of the North'.
The Birth of Venus was painted by Sandro Botticelli in the 1480s. It depicts the Roman goddess Venus emerging from the sea as a grown woman. The painting is housed in the Uffizi Gallery in Florence.
Las Meninas was painted by Diego Velázquez in 1656. It shows the Infanta Margarita Teresa surrounded by her entourage. The painting is famous for its complex composition and use of perspective.
The Persistence of Memory was painted by Salvador Dalí in 1931. It features melting clocks in a dreamlike landscape. The painting is one of the most recognizable surrealist works.
Water Lilies is a series of paintings by Claude Monet. He painted over 250 oil paintings of his flower garden at Giverny. The series spans from 1896 to 1926 and represents Impressionist art.
The Garden of Earthly Delights was painted by Hieronymus Bosch around 1515. It is a triptych showing paradise, earth, and hell. The painting is filled with fantastic and symbolic imagery.
Nighthawks was painted by Edward Hopper in 1942. It depicts people in a downtown diner late at night. The painting captures the loneliness and isolation of urban life.

The Creation of Adam was painted by Michelangelo on the Sistine Chapel ceiling around 1512. It shows God giving life to the first man, Adam. The scene is one of the most replicated religious paintings.
Campbell's Soup Cans were created by Andy Warhol in 1962. The artwork consists of 32 canvases, each showing a different soup flavor. It became an icon of the pop art movement.

A Sunday on La Grande Jatte was painted by Georges Seurat from 1884 to 1886. It depicts people relaxing in a park on an island in the Seine River. The painting was created using the pointillist technique.
The Kiss was painted by Gustav Klimt from 1907 to 1908. It shows a couple embracing and is covered in elaborate patterns and gold leaf. The painting represents the Vienna Secession movement.
Liberty Leading the People was painted by Eugène Delacroix in 1830. It commemorates the July Revolution in France. The painting shows Liberty personified as a woman leading people forward.
The Last Supper was painted by Leonardo da Vinci from 1495 to 1498. It depicts Jesus and his disciples at their final meal. The painting covers an entire wall of a convent in Milan.

Whistler's Mother was painted by James McNeill Whistler in 1871. Officially titled Arrangement in Grey and Black No. 1, it shows the artist's mother sitting in profile. The painting has become an icon of motherhood.
question: Who painted the Mona Lisa?

documents: Mount Everest stands 29,032 feet (8,849 meters) above sea level. It is located in the Himalayas on the border between Nepal and Tibet. Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay were the first to reach the summit in 1953.
K2 is the second-highest mountain in the world at 28,251 feet. It is located on the border between Pakistan and China. K2 is considered more difficult to climb than Everest.
Kangchenjunga is the third-highest mountain at 28,169 feet. It is located on the border between Nepal and India. The name means 'Five Treasures of Snow' referring to its five peaks.
Lhotse is the fourth-highest mountain at 27,940 feet. It is connected to Everest via the South Col. Lhotse means 'South Peak' in Tibetan.
Makalu is the fifth-highest mountain at 27,838 feet. It is located southeast of Mount Everest on the border between Nepal and Tibet. The mountain has a distinctive pyramid shape.
Cho Oyu is the sixth-highest mountain at 26,864 feet. It is located on the border between Tibet and Nepal. The name means 'Turquoise Goddess' in Tibetan.
Dhaulagiri is the seventh-highest mountain at 26,795 feet. It is located in Nepal and was once thought to be the highest mountain in the world. The name means 'White Mountain' in Sanskrit.
Manaslu is the eighth-highest mountain at 26,781 feet. It is located in Nepal and is known as the 'Mountain of the Spirit'. The mountain is popular with climbers seeking to prepare for Everest.

Nanga Parbat is the ninth-highest mountain at 26,660 feet. It is located in Pakistan and is known as the 'Killer Mountain' due to early climbing fatalities. It was the first 8,000-meter peak attempted by climbers.
Annapurna is the tenth-highest mountain at 26,545 feet. It is located in Nepal and was the first 8,000-meter peak to be climbed successfully. The mountain has a high fatality rate among climbers.
Gasherbrum I is the eleventh-highest mountain at 26,509 feet. It is located on the border between Pakistan and China. It is also known as Hidden Peak.
Broad Peak is the twelfth-highest mountain at 26,414 feet. It is located on the border between Pakistan and China. The mountain has a distinctive broad summit plateau.
Gasherbrum II is the thirteenth-highest mountain at 26,362 feet. It is located on the border between Pakistan and China. It is considered one of the easier 8,000-meter peaks to climb.

Shishapangma is the fourteenth-highest mountain at 26,335 feet. It is located entirely within Tibet and was the last of the 8,000-meter peaks to be climbed. The name means 'Crest Above the Grassy Plains'.
Gyachung Kang is a mountain peak at 26,089 feet. It is located on the border between Nepal and Tibet. It is the highest peak that is not considered one of the main 8,000-meter peaks.
Disteghil Sar is located in Pakistan and stands at 25,858 feet. It is the highest peak in the Hispar Muztagh subrange. The mountain was first climbed in 1960.
Himalchuli is located in Nepal and stands at 25,896 feet. It is part of the Mansiri Himal subrange. The mountain has two main summits connected by a ridge.
Ngadi Chuli is located in Nepal and stands at 25,812 feet. It is also known as Peak 29 and was first climbed in 1970. The mountain is part of the Mansiri Himal.
Nuptse is located near Mount Everest and stands at 25,791 feet. It forms part of the Everest massif along with Lhotse. The name means 'West Peak' in Tibetan.
Khunyang Chhish is located in Pakistan and stands at 25,761 feet. It is the second-highest peak in the Hispar Muztagh range. The mountain was first climbed in 1971.
question: What is the height of Mount Everest?

documents: Photosynthesis occurs in the chloroplasts of plant cells. It converts carbon dioxide and water into glucose using sunlight energy. The process releases oxygen as a byproduct essential for most life on Earth.

Mitosis is the process of cell division that produces two identical diploid cells. It consists of prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. Mitosis is essential for growth and repair in multicellular organisms.

Meiosis is a type of cell division that produces four genetically different haploid gametes. It involves two rounds of division and includes crossing over. Meiosis is crucial for sexual reproduction and genetic diversity.

Cellular respiration breaks down glucose to produce ATP energy. It occurs in three stages: glycolysis, Krebs cycle, and electron transport chain. The process requires oxygen and produces carbon dioxide and water.
Protein synthesis involves transcription and translation. DNA is transcribed into RNA, which is then translated into proteins. Ribosomes are the cellular machinery responsible for protein synthesis.
Enzyme function depends on their specific three-dimensional shape. They act as catalysts to speed up biochemical reactions. Enzymes can be denatured by changes in temperature or pH.
DNA replication occurs during the S phase of the cell cycle. The double helix unwinds and each strand serves as a template. DNA polymerase adds complementary nucleotides to form new strands.
Osmosis is the movement of water across semipermeable membranes. Water moves from areas of low solute concentration to high concentration. This process is vital for maintaining cell volume and shape.

Photosystem II and I work together in the light reactions of photosynthesis. They capture light energy and convert it to chemical energy. These reactions occur in the thylakoid membranes of chloroplasts.
Gene expression is regulated at multiple levels in cells. Transcription factors control which genes are transcribed into RNA. Epigenetic modifications can also affect gene expression patterns.
Active transport moves substances against concentration gradients using energy. It requires specific carrier proteins and ATP. Examples include the sodium-potassium pump in nerve cells.
Apoptosis is programmed cell death that occurs naturally in organisms. It helps eliminate damaged or unnecessary cells. Apoptosis is important for development and maintaining tissue health.
Fermentation is an anaerobic process that produces energy without oxygen. It occurs in muscle cells during intense exercise. Yeast fermentation produces alcohol and carbon dioxide.
The Calvin cycle is the light-independent reaction of photosynthesis. It uses ATP and NADPH to fix carbon dioxide into glucose. This cycle occurs in the stroma of chloroplasts.
Homeostasis maintains stable internal conditions in living organisms. It involves feedback mechanisms that detect and correct changes. Examples include temperature regulation and blood sugar control.
Genetic mutations are changes in DNA sequences. They can be caused by errors during replication or environmental factors. Some mutations are beneficial while others can be harmful.
Cellular differentiation is the process by which cells become specialized. Stem cells can differentiate into various cell types. This process is controlled by gene expression changes.
The citric acid cycle is part of cellular respiration. It occurs in the mitochondrial matrix and produces NADH and FADH2. These molecules carry electrons to the electron transport chain.
Passive transport moves substances down concentration gradients without energy. Examples include diffusion and facilitated diffusion. This process helps maintain cellular equilibrium.
Chromosomes contain DNA and proteins called histones. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes in most cells. Sex chromosomes determine biological sex in many organisms.
question: Where does photosynthesis occur in plant cells?

documents: The Pacific Ocean covers about 63 million square miles and is the largest ocean. It contains more than half of the world's free water. The Pacific is larger than all land masses combined.
The Atlantic Ocean is the second-largest ocean covering about 41 million square miles. It separates the Americas from Europe and Africa. The Mid-Atlantic Ridge runs through its center.
The Indian Ocean is the third-largest ocean covering about 27 million square miles. It is bounded by Africa, Asia, Australia, and Antarctica. The ocean is known for its warm temperatures.
The Arctic Ocean is the smallest ocean covering about 5.4 million square miles. It is mostly covered by sea ice throughout the year. The ocean surrounds the North Pole.
The Southern Ocean surrounds Antarctica and covers about 7.8 million square miles. It was officially recognized as the fifth ocean in 2000. The ocean has the strongest currents on Earth.
The Mediterranean Sea is an almost enclosed sea connected to the Atlantic Ocean. It covers about 970,000 square miles. The sea has been important for trade and civilization for thousands of years.
The Caribbean Sea is a marginal sea of the Atlantic Ocean. It covers about 1.06 million square miles. The sea is known for its warm, clear waters and coral reefs.
The North Sea is a marginal sea of the Atlantic Ocean. It is located between Great Britain and continental Europe. The sea is important for fishing and oil production.
The Red Sea is a narrow strip of water between Africa and Asia. It is known for its coral reefs and diverse marine life. The sea connects to the Indian Ocean through the Gulf of Aden.
The Baltic Sea is a marginal sea of the Atlantic Ocean. It is enclosed by Scandinavia and the Baltic countries. The sea has low salinity due to freshwater inflow.
The Persian Gulf is a shallow marginal sea of the Indian Ocean. It is located between Iran and the Arabian Peninsula. The gulf is important for oil production and shipping.
The Gulf of Mexico is a marginal sea of the Atlantic Ocean. It is bounded by the United States, Mexico, and Cuba. The gulf is known for its oil reserves and fishing industry.
The Coral Sea is a marginal sea of the Pacific Ocean. It is located off the northeast coast of Australia. The sea contains the Great Barrier Reef.
The Bering Sea is a marginal sea of the Pacific Ocean. It separates Asia and North America. The sea is known for its rich fishing grounds.
The Sea of Japan is a marginal sea of the Pacific Ocean. It is located between Japan and the Asian mainland. The sea is relatively deep with a maximum depth of over 12,000 feet.
The Tasman Sea is a marginal sea of the Pacific Ocean. It lies between Australia and New Zealand. The sea was named after Dutch explorer Abel Tasman.
The Arabian Sea is a region of the Indian Ocean. It is bounded by India, Pakistan, Iran, and the Arabian Peninsula. The sea is important for shipping and fishing.
The Bay of Bengal is the northeastern part of the Indian Ocean. It is bounded by India, Bangladesh, Myanmar, and Sri Lanka. The bay receives water from major rivers like the Ganges.
The South China Sea is a marginal sea of the Pacific Ocean. It is located in Southeast Asia and contains many disputed islands. The sea is important for international shipping routes.
question: Which is the largest ocean?

documents: The human heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles. The right side pumps blood to the lungs while the left side pumps to the body. Heart valves prevent blood from flowing backward.
The brain is divided into several regions including the cerebrum, cerebellum, and brainstem. The cerebrum controls thinking and voluntary movements. The cerebellum coordinates balance and movement.
The liver performs over 500 functions including detoxification and protein synthesis. It produces bile to help digest fats. The liver can regenerate itself if damaged.
The kidneys filter about 50 gallons of blood daily. They remove waste products and excess water from the body. Each kidney contains about one million filtering units called nephrons.
The lungs contain about 300 million alveoli for gas exchange. They remove carbon dioxide and add oxygen to the blood. The lungs expand and contract about 20,000 times per day.
The stomach produces hydrochloric acid to break down food. It has a muscular wall that churns food into a liquid called chyme. The stomach can hold about 1.5 liters of food.

The pancreas produces insulin to regulate blood sugar levels. It also produces digestive enzymes that break down proteins, fats, and carbohydrates. The pancreas has both endocrine and exocrine functions.
The small intestine is about 20 feet long and absorbs most nutrients. It has finger-like projections called villi that increase surface area. Most digestion is completed in the small intestine.
The large intestine absorbs water and forms solid waste. It contains beneficial bacteria that help with digestion. The large intestine is about 5 feet long.
The spleen filters blood and removes old red blood cells. It also stores platelets and white blood cells. The spleen is part of the lymphatic system.
The gallbladder stores and concentrates bile produced by the liver. It releases bile when fatty foods enter the small intestine. The gallbladder can be surgically removed if necessary.
The thyroid gland produces hormones that regulate metabolism. It is located in the neck and shaped like a butterfly. Thyroid disorders can affect weight, energy, and mood.
The adrenal glands produce stress hormones like cortisol and adrenaline. They sit on top of the kidneys. These hormones help the body respond to stress and danger.
The pituitary gland is called the master gland of the endocrine system. It produces hormones that control other glands. The pituitary is located at the base of the brain.
Bones provide structure and protect internal organs. They also produce blood cells in the bone marrow. Bones are living tissue that constantly remodel themselves.
Muscles contract to produce movement and maintain posture. There are three types: skeletal, cardiac, and smooth muscle. Skeletal muscles are under voluntary control.
The skin is the largest organ and provides protection from the environment. It helps regulate body temperature through sweating. Skin also produces vitamin D when exposed to sunlight.
Blood consists of red cells, white cells, platelets, and plasma. Red blood cells carry oxygen throughout the body. White blood cells fight infections and diseases.
The nervous system includes the brain, spinal cord, and nerves. It controls all body functions and processes sensory information. Nerve signals travel at speeds up to 120 meters per second.
The reproductive system enables humans to produce offspring. It includes organs that produce gametes and sex hormones. The system differs between males and females.
question: How many chambers does the human heart have?

documents: The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 meters per second. This is considered a fundamental constant of nature. Nothing with mass can travel faster than the speed of light.
Gravity is one of the four fundamental forces of nature. It attracts objects with mass toward each other. The strength of gravity depends on mass and distance between objects.
Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only converted from one form to another. This is known as the law of conservation of energy. Examples include kinetic, potential, and thermal energy.
Atoms consist of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Protons and neutrons form the nucleus while electrons orbit around it. The number of protons determines the element's identity.
Sound travels through air at approximately 343 meters per second at room temperature. Sound waves are vibrations that move through matter. Sound cannot travel through a vacuum.
Temperature is a measure of the average kinetic energy of particles. Absolute zero is -273.15°C or 0 Kelvin. At this temperature, all molecular motion theoretically stops.
Electric current is the flow of electric charge through a conductor. It is measured in amperes and follows Ohm's law. Current can be either direct (DC) or alternating (AC).
Magnetism is produced by moving electric charges or magnetic materials. Opposite magnetic poles attract while like poles repel. Earth has a magnetic field that protects us from solar wind.
Friction is a force that opposes motion between surfaces in contact. It converts kinetic energy into heat energy. Friction can be reduced by lubrication or smoother surfaces.
Pressure is force applied over an area and is measured in pascals. Atmospheric pressure at sea level is about 101,325 pascals. Pressure increases with depth in fluids.
Waves can be mechanical or electromagnetic and carry energy without transporting matter. They have properties like wavelength, frequency, and amplitude. Examples include sound waves and light waves.

Newton's first law states that objects at rest stay at rest unless acted upon by a force. This is also known as the law of inertia. Moving objects continue moving at constant velocity without external forces.

The electromagnetic spectrum includes radio waves, microwaves, infrared, visible light, ultraviolet, X-rays, and gamma rays. These differ in wavelength and frequency. Visible light is only a small portion of the spectrum.
Density is mass per unit volume and determines whether objects float or sink. Less dense materials float on more dense materials. Water has a density of 1 gram per cubic centimeter.
Work is done when a force moves an object through a distance. It is measured in joules and equals force times distance. No work is done if there is no movement.
Power is the rate at which work is done or energy is transferred. It is measured in watts where one watt equals one joule per second. Power determines how quickly energy is used.
Momentum is the product of mass and velocity. It is conserved in collisions between objects. Heavy, fast-moving objects have more momentum than light, slow-moving ones.
Heat is thermal energy that flows from hot to cold objects. It can be transferred by conduction, convection, or radiation. Heat always flows from higher to lower temperature.
Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity. It can be positive (speeding up) or negative (slowing down). Gravity causes objects to accelerate at 9.8 m/s² on Earth.
Electric charge comes in two types: positive and negative. Like charges repel while opposite charges attract. Charge is conserved and cannot be created or destroyed.
question: What is the speed of light in a vacuum?

documents: Coffee originated in Ethiopia and was first cultivated around the 9th century. It spread to Yemen and then throughout the Ottoman Empire. Coffee is now grown in over 70 countries worldwide.
Tea is the second most consumed beverage in the world after water. It originated in China around 2737 BC according to legend. There are four main types: black, green, white, and oolong.
Chocolate comes from cacao beans grown on trees in tropical regions. The Mayans and Aztecs used cacao as currency and in religious ceremonies. Milk chocolate was invented in 1875 by Daniel Peter.
Rice is a staple food for over half of the world's population. It is grown on every continent except Antarctica. There are over 40,000 varieties of rice worldwide.
Wheat is one of the most important cereal grains globally. It is used to make bread, pasta, and many other foods. Wheat was first domesticated around 9,600 BC in the Fertile Crescent.
Corn (maize) originated in Mexico around 9,000 years ago. It is now the most widely grown grain in the world. Corn is used for food, animal feed, and biofuel production.
Potatoes originated in the Andes Mountains of South America. They were introduced to Europe in the 16th century. Potatoes are the world's fourth-largest food crop.
Tomatoes are technically fruits but are commonly used as vegetables. They originated in South America and were brought to Europe by Spanish conquistadors. Tomatoes were once thought to be poisonous.
Bananas are the world's most popular fruit. They grow on plants that are actually the world's largest herbs. Most commercial bananas are seedless and reproduced through cloning.

Apples originated in Central Asia and have been cultivated for thousands of years. There are over 7,500 apple varieties worldwide. The saying 'an apple a day keeps the doctor away' has some scientific basis.
Oranges are citrus fruits that originated in Southeast Asia. They are rich in vitamin C and helped prevent scurvy among sailors. Brazil is the world's largest orange producer.
Grapes have been cultivated for over 8,000 years. They are used to make wine, juice, and eaten fresh. There are over 10,000 grape varieties worldwide.
Carrots were originally purple, not orange. The orange variety was developed in the Netherlands in the 17th century. Carrots are rich in beta-carotene, which the body converts to vitamin A.
Onions have been cultivated for over 5,000 years. They were valued by ancient Egyptians and even used as currency. Onions make people cry because they release sulfur compounds when cut.
Garlic has been used for both culinary and medicinal purposes for thousands of years. It was given to Olympic athletes in ancient Greece. Garlic has antimicrobial and cardiovascular benefits.
Honey is produced by bees from flower nectar. It never spoils due to its low moisture content and acidic pH. Honey has been found in ancient Egyptian tombs and was still edible.
Salt has been essential for food preservation throughout history. It was once so valuable it was used as currency. The human body needs salt to function properly but too much can be harmful.
Sugar was first extracted from sugar cane in India around 350 AD. It was a luxury item in Europe until sugar beets were developed. The average American consumes about 17 teaspoons of sugar daily.
Milk is produced by mammals to feed their young. Cow's milk is the most commonly consumed type worldwide. Many adults are lactose intolerant and cannot digest milk sugar.
Eggs are one of the most complete protein sources available. They have been consumed by humans for thousands of years. The color of an eggshell depends on the breed of chicken.
question: Where did coffee originate?

documents: The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States in 1886. It stands 305 feet tall including its pedestal. The statue was designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi and represents freedom and democracy.
The Eiffel Tower was built for the 1889 World's Fair in Paris. It is 324 meters tall and was the world's tallest structure until 1930. The tower is made of iron and weighs about 10,100 tons.
Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell in the clock tower of Westminster Palace. The tower itself is officially called Elizabeth Tower. Big Ben chimes every hour and is a symbol of London.
The Colosseum in Rome was completed in 80 AD. It could hold up to 80,000 spectators for gladiatorial contests. The structure has a complex system of underground chambers called the hypogeum.
Machu Picchu was built by the Incas in the 15th century. It sits at 7,972 feet above sea level in Peru. The site was abandoned during the Spanish conquest and rediscovered in 1911.
The Great Wall of China stretches over 13,000 miles. It was built over many centuries by various Chinese dynasties. Contrary to popular belief, it is not visible from space with the naked eye.

The Taj Mahal was built as a tomb for Emperor Shah Jahan's wife Mumtaz. Construction took 22 years and was completed in 1653. The building is made of white marble and is considered a masterpiece of architecture.
Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument in England consisting of standing stones. It was built in several phases between 3100 and 1600 BC. The purpose of Stonehenge remains a mystery to archaeologists.
Christ the Redeemer statue overlooks Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It stands 98 feet tall and was completed in 1931. The statue is made of reinforced concrete and soapstone.
The Sydney Opera House is famous for its distinctive shell-shaped design. It was designed by Danish architect Jørn Utzon and opened in 1973. The building houses multiple performance venues.
The Golden Gate Bridge spans the Golden Gate strait in San Francisco. It opened in 1937 and was the world's longest suspension bridge at the time. The bridge is painted in International Orange color.
Mount Rushmore features the faces of four US presidents carved into granite. The sculpture was created between 1927 and 1941 by Gutzon Borglum. Each face is about 60 feet tall.
The Tower Bridge in London was completed in 1894. It is a bascule and suspension bridge that can open to allow ships to pass. The bridge has become an iconic symbol of London.
Neuschwanstein Castle in Germany was built by King Ludwig II. Construction began in 1869 and was never fully completed. The castle inspired Disney's Sleeping Beauty Castle.

The Parthenon was built in ancient Athens between 447 and 432 BC. It was dedicated to the goddess Athena and is considered the finest example of Doric architecture. The building has been damaged by wars and earthquakes over the centuries.
Petra in Jordan is an ancient city carved into red sandstone cliffs. It was built by the Nabataeans around the 4th century BC. Petra was lost to the Western world until 1812.
Angkor Wat in Cambodia is the largest religious monument in the world. It was built in the early 12th century as a Hindu temple. The complex covers over 400 acres.

The Kremlin in Moscow is a fortified complex that serves as the seat of Russian government. It was built in the 15th century and contains palaces, cathedrals, and government buildings. The complex is surrounded by red brick walls.
Chichen Itza was a major Maya city in Mexico. The site features the famous El Castillo pyramid and a large ball court. It was one of the largest Maya cities and thrived from 600 to 1200 AD.

The Leaning Tower of Pisa began tilting during construction in the 12th century. The tower leans at an angle of about 3.97 degrees. Various efforts have been made to stabilize the tower over the centuries.
question: When was the Statue of Liberty given to the United States?

documents: The Amazon River is approximately 4,000 miles long, making it the longest river in the world. It flows through several South American countries including Peru, Colombia, and Brazil. The river system drains about 40% of South America.

The Nile River has historically been considered the world's longest river at about 4,135 miles. It flows through eleven countries in northeastern Africa. The Nile has two main tributaries: the White Nile and Blue Nile.
The Mississippi River is the longest river in North America at 2,320 miles. It flows from Minnesota to the Gulf of Mexico. The river system drains about 40% of the continental United States.

The Yangtze River is the longest river in Asia at 3,915 miles. It flows through China from Tibet to the East China Sea. The river is important for transportation, agriculture, and hydroelectric power.

The Congo River is the second-longest river in Africa at 2,920 miles. It flows through the Democratic Republic of Congo and other Central African countries. The river has the second-largest flow in the world after the Amazon.
The Mekong River flows for 2,703 miles through Southeast Asia. It passes through China, Myanmar, Laos, Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam. The river is vital for fishing and agriculture in the region.
The Lena River flows for 2,736 miles through Russia. It starts in the Baikal Mountains and flows north to the Arctic Ocean. The river freezes for about seven months each year.
The Mackenzie River is the longest river in Canada at 2,635 miles. It flows from Great Slave Lake to the Arctic Ocean. The river system drains much of northwestern Canada.
The Niger River flows for 2,597 miles through West Africa. It passes through Guinea, Mali, Niger, Benin, and Nigeria. The river forms an unusual boomerang shape as it flows.
The Murray River is Australia's longest river at 1,558 miles. It flows from the Australian Alps to the Southern Ocean. The river is important for irrigation and agriculture in southeastern Australia.
The Volga River is Europe's longest river at 2,294 miles. It flows through Russia from the Valdai Hills to the Caspian Sea. The river is culturally and economically important to Russia.
The Danube River flows for 1,770 miles through Central and Eastern Europe. It passes through ten countries including Germany, Austria, and Romania. The river empties into the Black Sea.
The Rhine River flows for 766 miles through Western Europe. It passes through Switzerland, Germany, France, and the Netherlands. The river is one of the most important waterways in Europe.
The Ganges River flows for 1,569 miles through India and Bangladesh. It is considered sacred in Hinduism and supports hundreds of millions of people. The river faces severe pollution challenges.
The Indus River flows for 1,976 miles through Tibet, India, and Pakistan. It gave its name to India and the Indus Valley Civilization. The river is crucial for agriculture in Pakistan.

The Colorado River flows for 1,450 miles through the southwestern United States and Mexico. It carved the Grand Canyon over millions of years. The river is heavily used for water supply and hydroelectric power.
The Thames River flows for 215 miles through southern England. It passes through London and empties into the North Sea. The river has been central to British history and culture.
The Seine River flows for 482 miles through northern France. It passes through Paris and empties into the English Channel. The river is famous for its role in French culture and history.
The Euphrates River flows for 1,740 miles through Turkey, Syria, and Iraq. It is one of the rivers that defined ancient Mesopotamia. The river faces challenges from dam construction and drought.

The Jordan River flows for 156 miles from the Sea of Galilee to the Dead Sea. It is significant in Christianity, Judaism, and Islam. The river has been heavily diverted for agriculture and water supply.
question: Where does the Amazon River flow?
answer: South America, including Peru, Colombia, and Brazil.

documents: William Shakespeare lived from 1564 to 1616 during the Elizabethan era. He wrote approximately 39 plays and 154 sonnets during his career. Shakespeare is widely considered the greatest English-language writer.

Charles Dickens was a Victorian novelist who lived from 1812 to 1870. He wrote classics like A Tale of Two Cities and Great Expectations. Dickens was known for his social criticism and memorable characters.
Jane Austen lived from 1775 to 1817 and wrote six major novels. Her works include Pride and Prejudice and Emma. Austen's novels critique the British landed gentry with wit and social commentary.
Mark Twain was the pen name of Samuel Clemens (1835-1910). He wrote The Adventures of Tom Sawyer and Adventures of Huckleberry Finn. Twain is known for his humor and portrayal of American life.
Virginia Woolf lived from 1882 to 1941 and was a modernist writer. She wrote novels like Mrs. Dalloway and To the Lighthouse. Woolf was also an important feminist and literary critic.

Ernest Hemingway lived from 1899 to 1961 and won both the Pulitzer and Nobel prizes. He wrote The Old Man and the Sea and A Farewell to Arms. Hemingway was known for his spare, understated writing style.
F. Scott Fitzgerald lived from 1896 to 1940 and wrote The Great Gatsby. He captured the Jazz Age and the American Dream in his works. Fitzgerald struggled with alcoholism and financial problems.
George Orwell was the pen name of Eric Blair (1903-1950). He wrote 1984 and Animal Farm, both critiques of totalitarianism. Orwell also wrote essays and worked as a journalist.
Emily Dickinson lived from 1830 to 1886 and was a reclusive American poet. She wrote nearly 1,800 poems, most published after her death. Dickinson's poetry is known for its unique style and themes.
Leo Tolstoy lived from 1828 to 1910 and was a Russian novelist. He wrote War and Peace and Anna Karenina. Tolstoy is considered one of the greatest novelists of all time.
Agatha Christie lived from 1890 to 1976 and was a British mystery writer. She created detectives Hercule Poirot and Miss Marple. Christie is the best-selling novelist of all time.
J.K. Rowling was born in 1965 and created the Harry Potter series. The seven-book series has sold over 500 million copies worldwide. Rowling became the first billionaire author.
Stephen King was born in 1947 and is known for horror and supernatural fiction. He has written over 60 novels and 200 short stories. Many of King's works have been adapted for film and television.
Maya Angelou lived from 1928 to 2014 and was an American poet and memoirist. She wrote I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings. Angelou was also a civil rights activist.
Toni Morrison lived from 1931 to 2019 and won the Nobel Prize in Literature. She wrote Beloved and Song of Solomon. Morrison's works often dealt with African American experiences.
Gabriel García Márquez lived from 1927 to 2014 and was a Colombian novelist. He wrote One Hundred Years of Solitude and won the Nobel Prize. García Márquez pioneered magical realism.
Harper Lee lived from 1926 to 2016 and wrote To Kill a Mockingbird. The novel won the Pulitzer Prize and addressed racial injustice. Lee published very few works during her lifetime.
Kurt Vonnegut lived from 1922 to 2007 and was known for satirical and science fiction works. He wrote Slaughterhouse-Five and Cat's Cradle. Vonnegut's work often dealt with war and human folly.
Zora Neale Hurston lived from 1891 to 1960 and was part of the Harlem Renaissance. She wrote Their Eyes Were Watching God. Hurston was also an anthropologist who studied African American folklore.
James Joyce lived from 1882 to 1941 and was an Irish modernist writer. He wrote Ulysses and Finnegans Wake. Joyce's experimental style greatly influenced 20th-century literature.
question: During which years did William Shakespeare live?

documents: The blue whale is the largest animal that has ever lived on Earth. Adults can reach lengths of up to 100 feet and weigh as much as 200 tons. Blue whales feed primarily on tiny shrimp-like creatures called krill.

African elephants are the largest land animals currently alive. Adult males can weigh up to 13,000 pounds and stand 13 feet tall. They have larger ears than Asian elephants to help regulate body temperature.

The giraffe is the tallest mammal with males reaching heights of 18 feet. Their long necks contain the same number of vertebrae as humans. Giraffes can run up to 35 miles per hour despite their height.
Saltwater crocodiles are the largest living reptiles. They can grow up to 23 feet long and weigh over 2,000 pounds. These apex predators are found in Southeast Asia and northern Australia.
The ostrich is the largest and heaviest bird in the world. They can stand up to 9 feet tall and weigh up to 350 pounds. Despite being flightless, ostriches can run up to 45 miles per hour.
Polar bears are the largest carnivorous land mammals. Adult males can weigh up to 1,500 pounds and stand 10 feet tall on hind legs. They are excellent swimmers and primarily hunt seals.

The Kodiak bear is one of the largest subspecies of brown bear. They can weigh up to 1,500 pounds and are found only on islands in Alaska. Kodiak bears are omnivores but prefer salmon during spawning season.
Siberian tigers are the largest wild cats in the world. They can grow up to 11 feet long and weigh up to 660 pounds. These endangered cats are found primarily in Russia and China.
The wandering albatross has the largest wingspan of any bird. Their wings can span up to 12 feet from tip to tip. These seabirds can glide for hours without flapping their wings.
Giant Pacific octopuses are the largest octopus species. They can have arm spans of up to 30 feet and weigh up to 600 pounds. These intelligent creatures can change color and texture instantly.
Sperm whales have the largest brains of any animal on Earth. Their brains can weigh up to 17 pounds. Sperm whales can dive to depths of over 7,000 feet to hunt giant squid.
The leatherback sea turtle is the largest turtle species. They can weigh up to 2,000 pounds and measure 7 feet long. Leatherbacks can dive to depths of over 4,000 feet.
Colossal squids are among the largest invertebrates on Earth. They can grow up to 46 feet long including tentacles. These deep-sea creatures have the largest eyes in the animal kingdom.
The capybara is the largest rodent in the world. They can weigh up to 140 pounds and are native to South America. Capybaras are semi-aquatic and excellent swimmers.
Moose are the largest members of the deer family. Adult males can weigh up to 1,500 pounds and stand 6.5 feet tall at the shoulder. Their antlers can span up to 6 feet across.
The emperor penguin is the largest penguin species. They can stand up to 4 feet tall and weigh up to 88 pounds. Emperor penguins can dive to depths of over 1,800 feet.
Manta rays are the largest rays in the ocean. Their wingspan can reach up to 29 feet across. Despite their size, manta rays feed on tiny plankton and small fish.
The Goliath beetle is one of the largest insects by weight. They can weigh up to 3.5 ounces and measure 4 inches long. These beetles are found in Africa's tropical forests.
Flemish Giant rabbits are among the largest domestic rabbit breeds. They can weigh up to 22 pounds and measure over 2 feet long. These gentle giants were originally bred in Belgium.
The Japanese spider crab has the largest leg span of any arthropod. Their legs can span up to 12 feet from claw to claw. These crabs live in deep waters around Japan.
question: What is the largest animal that has ever lived on Earth?

documents: Gold has the chemical symbol Au, derived from the Latin word 'aurum.' It is a precious metal that is highly resistant to corrosion and tarnishing. Gold has been used as currency and jewelry for over 4,000 years.

Silver has the chemical symbol Ag from the Latin 'argentum.' It has the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of all elements. Silver has antimicrobial properties and is used in medical applications.
Iron has the chemical symbol Fe from the Latin 'ferrum.' It is the most abundant element on Earth by mass and forms the planet's core. Iron is essential for oxygen transport in blood.

Copper has the chemical symbol Cu from the Latin 'cuprum.' It is an excellent conductor of electricity and develops a green patina when exposed to air. Copper is essential for many biological processes.
Lead has the chemical symbol Pb from the Latin 'plumbum.' It is a heavy metal that is toxic to humans, especially children. Lead was once commonly used in paint and gasoline.
Tin has the chemical symbol Sn from the Latin 'stannum.' It is used to coat other metals to prevent corrosion. Tin was one of the first metals to be extracted and used by humans.
Mercury has the chemical symbol Hg from the Latin 'hydrargyrum.' It is the only metal that is liquid at room temperature. Mercury is highly toxic and can cause neurological damage.
