Platinum has the chemical symbol Pt and is rarer than gold. It is used in catalytic converters and jewelry. Platinum is highly resistant to corrosion and has a high melting point.
Uranium has the chemical symbol U and is radioactive. It is used as fuel in nuclear reactors and weapons. Uranium naturally occurs in rocks and soil throughout the world.
Tungsten has the chemical symbol W from the German 'wolfram.' It has the highest melting point of all elements at 3,695°C. Tungsten is used in light bulb filaments and cutting tools.
Aluminum has the chemical symbol Al and is the most abundant metal in Earth's crust. It is lightweight and resistant to corrosion. Aluminum is widely used in packaging and transportation.
Zinc has the chemical symbol Zn and is essential for human health. It is used to galvanize steel to prevent rusting. Zinc deficiency can cause growth problems and immune dysfunction.
Nickel has the chemical symbol Ni and is used to make stainless steel. It is magnetic and resistant to corrosion. Some people are allergic to nickel and develop skin reactions.
Titanium has the chemical symbol Ti and has a high strength-to-weight ratio. It is biocompatible and used in medical implants. Titanium is also used in aerospace applications.
Chromium has the chemical symbol Cr and gives stainless steel its corrosion resistance. It is used in chrome plating and pigments. Chromium compounds can be toxic in certain forms.
Cobalt has the chemical symbol Co and is used in rechargeable batteries. It is magnetic and used in high-temperature alloys. Cobalt is essential for vitamin B12 synthesis.
Manganese has the chemical symbol Mn and is essential for steel production. It is also important for bone formation and metabolism. Manganese deficiency is rare but can affect growth.
Molybdenum has the chemical symbol Mo and is used in steel alloys. It has a high melting point and is used in high-temperature applications. Molybdenum is essential for certain enzymes.
Vanadium has the chemical symbol V and is used to strengthen steel. It is named after Vanadis, a Norse goddess. Vanadium compounds are used as catalysts in chemical reactions.
Antimony has the chemical symbol Sb from the Latin 'stibium.' It is used in flame retardants and semiconductors. Antimony has been used since ancient times in cosmetics and medicine.
question: What is the chemical symbol for gold?

documents: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) was launched on December 25, 2021. It orbits the Sun at the second Lagrange point (L2). JWST's infrared capabilities allow it to observe ancient galaxies.
The Hubble Space Telescope was launched in 1990. It operates in low Earth orbit and captures visible/ultraviolet light. Hubble helped determine the universe's expansion rate.
Mars rovers like Perseverance search for signs of ancient life. They collect soil samples for potential return to Earth. Perseverance landed in Jezero Crater in 2021.
Voyager 1 is the farthest human-made object from Earth. It entered interstellar space in 2012. The probe carries a Golden Record with sounds of Earth.
Saturn's rings are primarily composed of ice particles. The rings extend up to 175,000 miles from the planet. Cassini spacecraft studied Saturn for 13 years.
The International Space Station (ISS) orbits Earth every 90 minutes. It has been continuously inhabited since 2000. Astronauts conduct experiments in microgravity.
Black holes form when massive stars collapse. Their gravity is so strong that light cannot escape. Sagittarius A* is the Milky Way's central black hole.
Neutron stars result from supernova explosions. A teaspoon of neutron star material weighs billions of tons. They emit pulsar signals when rotating rapidly.
Venus has a surface temperature of 864°F due to greenhouse gases. Its atmosphere is 96% carbon dioxide. Venus rotates backward compared to other planets.
The Moon's gravity causes Earth's tides. It is moving away from Earth at 1.5 inches yearly. Apollo missions brought 842 lbs of lunar samples to Earth.
Auroras occur when solar particles collide with Earth's magnetosphere. They appear near polar regions. The colors depend on atmospheric gases involved.
Exoplanets are planets orbiting stars beyond our solar system. The Kepler telescope discovered over 2,600 exoplanets. Some exist in habitable zones.
Solar flares release energy equivalent to billions of hydrogen bombs. They can disrupt satellite communications. The Carrington Event (1859) was the largest recorded flare.
Mercury has extreme temperature fluctuations (-290°F to 800°F). It completes an orbit in 88 Earth days. Mercury has no moons or rings.
Jupiter's Great Red Spot is a giant storm lasting centuries. The planet has 95 known moons. Juno spacecraft studies Jupiter's composition and magnetosphere.
Comets are icy bodies that develop tails near the Sun. Halley's Comet appears every 76 years. The Rosetta mission landed on comet 67P in 2014.
Dark matter constitutes 27% of the universe's mass-energy. It doesn't emit light but influences galaxy rotation. Its exact nature remains unknown.
The Andromeda Galaxy is the Milky Way's nearest spiral neighbor. It will collide with our galaxy in 4.5 billion years. Andromeda contains a trillion stars.
Gamma-ray bursts are the universe's most energetic explosions. They last milliseconds to minutes. Most originate from collapsing massive stars.
Pluto was reclassified as a dwarf planet in 2006. It has five moons, including Charon. New Horizons provided detailed Pluto images in 2015.
question: When was the James Webb Space Telescope launched?

documents: Elephants have a gestation period of 22 months, the longest of any land animal. Calves weigh 200-250 lbs at birth. Herds are matriarchal, led by the oldest female.

Polar bears have black skin under white fur for heat absorption. They primarily hunt seals. Climate change threatens their sea ice habitat.

Bats are the only mammals capable of sustained flight. Echolocation helps them navigate in darkness. Some species pollinate agave plants.
Tigers have unique stripe patterns for camouflage. They are solitary hunters. Over 90% of wild tigers live in India and Southeast Asia.
Zebras' stripes confuse predators and deter biting flies. Each pattern is unique like fingerprints. They graze alongside wildebeests for protection.
Crocodiles have existed for 200 million years. They can hold their breath underwater for an hour. Jaw muscles exert 3,700 psi of force.
Armadillos roll into balls for protection. They give birth to identical quadruplets. Some species carry leprosy bacteria.
Sloths move so slowly that algae grow on their fur. They descend trees weekly to defecate. Their metabolism is 40-45% slower than similar mammals.
Orcas hunt in pods using coordinated strategies. They have distinct dialects. Wild orcas live 50-90 years, longer than captive ones.

question: How long is an elephant's gestation period?

question: Where is the Mona Lisa displayed?

documents: The human heart beats 100,000 times daily. It pumps 2,000 gallons of blood each day. The heart has four chambers and valves.
The brain contains 86 billion neurons. It uses 20% of the body's oxygen. Neuroplasticity allows learning throughout life.

Skin is the body's largest organ. It sheds 30,000-40,000 cells per minute. Melanin determines skin pigmentation.
Bones contain 99% of the body's calcium. Osteoblasts build bone; osteoclasts break it down. The femur can support 30x body weight.
Muscles constitute 40% of body weight. Fast-twitch fibers enable sprinting; slow-twitch aid endurance. ATP provides energy for contraction.
The small intestine is 22 feet long. Villi increase surface area for nutrient absorption. Most digestion occurs here.
Eyes perceive color via cone cells. The cornea bends light; the lens focuses it. Myopia (nearsightedness) affects 30% of people.
Blood consists of plasma (55%), red cells, white cells, and platelets. Type O is the universal donor. Hemoglobin carries oxygen.
The pancreas produces insulin and digestive enzymes. Diabetes results from insulin dysfunction. Islet cells regulate blood sugar.
The spleen filters blood and stores platelets. It recycles old red blood cells. Removal (splenectomy) increases infection risk.
The thyroid regulates metabolism via hormones. Goiter indicates iodine deficiency. Hyperthyroidism speeds bodily functions.
Adrenal glands produce fight-or-flight hormones. Cortisol manages stress responses. Addison's disease involves adrenal insufficiency.
The gallbladder stores bile for fat digestion. Gallstones can block bile ducts. Removal doesn't significantly impact digestion.
The large intestine absorbs water and forms feces. Gut microbiota aid digestion. Fiber promotes bowel regularity.
Hair grows 0.5 inches monthly. Each follicle cycles through growth phases. Male pattern baldness involves DHT hormone sensitivity.
Nails grow from the matrix at 3mm monthly. Fingernails grow faster than toenails. Ridges may indicate nutritional deficiencies.

The Boston Globe's Spotlight team exposed church abuse in 2002. Their investigation won a Pulitzer. The Catholic Church hid 1,000 predator priests.
Twitter revolutionized breaking news in the 2000s. Citizen journalists reported events faster than media. Hashtags organized global conversations.
Vice Media pioneered gonzo digital journalism. Its 2014 Islamic State documentary was controversial. The company filed for bankruptcy in 2023.
The Associated Press formed in 1846 as a cooperative. Its style guide standardizes media writing. AP supplies news to 15,000 organizations.
60 Minutes has aired since 1968. Its stopwatch intro is iconic. Mike Wallace's tough interviews defined investigative TV journalism.
The Drudge Report broke the Lewinsky scandal in 1998. Matt Drudge operated the aggregation site alone. Its red siren alerts signal major scoops.
ProPublica won Pulitzers as a nonprofit newsroom. Its investigative work focuses on public interest. Major donors include the Sandler Foundation.
The Onion satirizes news since 1988. Its headlines like 'Area Man' became cultural shorthand. The site was mistaken as real by Chinese media.
The Wall Street Journal's paywall succeeded where others failed. Its 2.3 million subscribers fund investigative work. The hedge fund style is distinctive.
Politico launched in 2007 covering Capitol Hill. Its Playbook newsletter dominates DC mornings. The outlet expanded to European markets.
BuzzFeed News closed in 2023 despite Pulitzers. Its viral quizzes funded serious journalism. The site pioneered native advertising ('listicles').
question: When was Reuters begin as a pigeon message service?

documents: The first radio broadcast was in 1906 by Reginald Fessenden. He played 'O Holy Night' on violin. Ships at sea heard the transmission.
KDKA Pittsburgh aired the first commercial broadcast in 1920. It reported Harding's presidential victory. The station still operates today.
The BBC formed in 1922 as the British Broadcasting Company. John Reith established its public service ethos. The first news bulletin had no vowels to avoid bias.
War of the Worlds caused panic in 1938. Orson Welles' dramatization seemed like real news. The FCC later banned simulated news bulletins.
Top 40 radio format began in 1951. Todd Storz noticed bar patrons replaying jukebox hits. The format dominated until streaming emerged.
Wolfman Jack's growling voice defined 1960s rock radio. He broadcast from Mexico at 250,000 watts. The DJ appeared in American Graffiti.
NPR launched in 1971 with All Things Considered. Public radio avoided commercials. Car Talk and Prairie Home Companion became staples.
Howard Stern revolutionized morning radio in the 1980s. His shock jock style earned huge ratings. SiriusXM paid $500 million for his show.
BBC Radio 1 debuted in 1967 for pop music. The pirate radio boom prompted its creation. John Peel's late-night show championed underground acts.
Clear Channel dominated US radio after 1996 deregulation. It owned 1,200 stations by 2000. Automated voice tracking replaced local DJs.
Podcasting began with RSS feeds in 2004. Serial (2014) made the medium mainstream. Joe Rogan's Spotify deal was worth $200 million.
Radio Free Europe broadcast behind the Iron Curtain. Funded secretly by the CIA until 1971. It provided uncensored news to communist countries.
Radio Caroline defied UK broadcasting laws in 1964. The pirate ship anchored in international waters. The 1967 Marine Act shut it down.
Tokyo Rose was WWII propaganda. Several women broadcast for Japan. Iva Toguri served six years before pardon.
Radiohead named after a Talking Heads song. The band originally called themselves On a Friday. Their OK Computer predicted digital alienation.
Radio Ga Ga criticized declining radio quality. Queen's 1984 hit inspired Lady Gaga's name. The video used footage from Metropolis.
CB radio peaked in the 1970s. Truckers used '10-codes' like '10-4'. Smokey and the Bandit popularized citizen's band culture.
Radio astronomy discovered cosmic microwaves in 1965. Arno Penzias found the Big Bang's afterglow. The static was initially blamed on pigeon droppings.
Ham radio operators assist in disasters. They relay messages when networks fail. Licenses require passing Morse code until 2007.
Radio Luxembourg reached Europe at night. Its English service influenced 1950s youth. DJs promoted rock against BBC's conservative playlists.
question: What was the first radio station to make a commercial broadcast?

documents: Visa began as BankAmericard in 1958. The first mass mailing resulted in fraud. The name changed to Visa in 1976 for international appeal.
The first credit card was Diners Club in 1950. Frank McNamara forgot his wallet at dinner. The cardboard card initially had 200 members.
American Express launched its card in 1958. It required full monthly payment. The company already dominated traveler's checks.
MasterCard started as Interbank in 1966. California banks formed a competitor to BankAmericard. It rebranded in 1979 with overlapping circles logo.
The magnetic stripe was invented in 1969 by IBM. Forrest Parry glued tape to plastic. It standardized card data storage globally.
EMV chips reduced counterfeit fraud in the 1990s. The name comes from Europay, MasterCard, Visa. Chip-and-PIN is standard in Europe.
Contactless payments use NFC technology. London buses adopted it in 2012. A wave symbol indicates tap-to-pay capability.
Apple Pay launched in 2014 with tokenization. It stores virtual card numbers for security. Over 500 million users exist globally.
Credit scores were invented in 1989 by Fair Isaac. FICO ranges from 300-850. Payment history weighs 35% of the calculation.
The CARD Act of 2009 protected consumers. It limited rate hikes and fees. Credit card agreements became shorter and clearer.
Black cards have no spending limits. The Centurion requires $250,000 annual spending. American Express invites only high-net-worth clients.
Balance transfers move debt between cards. Introductory 0% APR offers attract customers. Fees are typically 3-5% of the transferred amount.
Cashback rewards average 1-2% of spending. Some cards offer 5% on rotating categories. Points systems allow flexible redemption options.
Credit card skimmers steal data at ATMs. Overlays on gas pumps are common. EMV chips reduced this fraud by 76%.
The first universal travel card was Thomas Cook's in 1874. The 'circular note' worked like traveler's checks. Hotels and shops accepted it globally.
Store cards have higher interest rates. Retailers profit from financing purchases. Target's REDcard gives 5% discount at checkout.
Charge cards require full monthly payment. Unlike credit cards, they have no preset limit. American Express and Diners Club remain popular.
Virtual cards generate for online purchases. They prevent merchant overcharging. Banks issue temporary numbers for single-use transactions.
Credit card debt reached $1 trillion in 2023. The average household owes $7,951. Minimum payments mostly cover interest, not principal.
The Durbin Amendment capped debit card fees in 2010. It saved retailers $8 billion annually. Banks responded by eliminating free checking accounts.

documents: Earth is the third planet from the Sun and the only one known to support life. It has one natural satellite, the Moon, and diverse ecosystems across its surface.

Jupiter is the largest planet in our solar system and is primarily composed of hydrogen and helium. It has a massive storm system known as the Great Red Spot. The planet has at least 79 moons, including Ganymede, the largest moon in the solar system.
Mars is known as the Red Planet due to its iron oxide-rich surface. It has two moons, Phobos and Deimos, and features the tallest volcano in the solar system, Olympus Mons.
Saturn is famous for its extensive ring system, composed mainly of ice particles and rocky debris. It is the sixth planet from the Sun and has over 80 moons, including Titan.
Venus has a thick atmosphere primarily made of carbon dioxide and sulfuric acid clouds. It has surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead and is similar in size to Earth.
Mercury, the closest planet to the Sun, has no atmosphere to speak of and experiences extreme temperature variations. It is also the smallest of the eight planets.
Uranus rotates on its side relative to its orbit, which results in unusual seasonal changes. It has a faint ring system and is classified as an ice giant.
Neptune is a distant, blue-colored planet known for its strong winds and storms. It was discovered in 1846 and has a faint ring system and many moons.
Pluto, once considered the ninth planet, is now classified as a dwarf planet. It orbits the Sun in the Kuiper Belt and has five known moons.
Ceres is the largest object in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. It is considered a dwarf planet and has a surface of ice and rock.
Europa is one of Jupiter’s moons and is believed to have a subsurface ocean beneath its icy crust. It is a candidate for the search for extraterrestrial life.
Io, another of Jupiter’s moons, is the most volcanically active body in the solar system. Its surface is dotted with sulfur-rich eruptions.
The asteroid belt lies between the orbits of Mars and Jupiter. It contains numerous irregularly shaped objects and dwarf planets like Ceres.
The Kuiper Belt is a region of the solar system beyond Neptune that contains icy bodies and dwarf planets. Pluto is one of its most well-known members.
The Oort Cloud is a theoretical cloud of icy bodies surrounding the solar system. It is believed to be the source of long-period comets.
Comets are icy bodies that release gas and dust when near the Sun, forming a glowing coma and tail. They originate from the Kuiper Belt and Oort Cloud.
The Sun is a G-type main-sequence star that provides the energy needed for life on Earth. It formed about 4.6 billion years ago from a molecular cloud.
The solar wind is a stream of charged particles released from the Sun's upper atmosphere. It affects planetary magnetospheres and causes auroras on Earth.
Exoplanets are planets that orbit stars outside our solar system. Thousands have been discovered, and some may be in the habitable zone of their stars.
The heliosphere is a vast bubble-like region of space dominated by the solar wind and magnetic field of the Sun. It extends well beyond Pluto's orbit.
question: Which planet in solar system is the only one known to support life?

documents: The Eiffel Tower was completed in 1889 as the entrance arch to the World’s Fair in Paris. Designed by Gustave Eiffel, it became a global cultural icon of France. The tower is 324 meters tall and made of iron.
The Colosseum is a large amphitheater in Rome built during the Roman Empire. It hosted gladiatorial contests and public spectacles. Today, it is a major tourist attraction and symbol of ancient Rome.
The Great Wall of China stretches over 13,000 miles and was built to protect Chinese states from invasions. It is made of stone, brick, tamped earth, and other materials.
The Taj Mahal is a white marble mausoleum in Agra, India, commissioned by Emperor Shah Jahan. It is a UNESCO World Heritage Site and a symbol of love.
Big Ben is the nickname for the Great Bell of the clock at the north end of the Palace of Westminster in London. It has become an iconic landmark in the United Kingdom.
The Sydney Opera House is one of the most famous buildings of the 20th century, located on Sydney Harbour. It is known for its unique sail-like design.
The Statue of Liberty was a gift from France to the United States, unveiled in 1886. It stands on Liberty Island in New York Harbor.
Machu Picchu is a 15th-century Inca citadel located in the Andes Mountains of Peru. It was rediscovered in 1911 by Hiram Bingham.
Christ the Redeemer is a large statue of Jesus Christ in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It stands 30 meters tall and overlooks the city from Mount Corcovado.
The Leaning Tower of Pisa is known for its unintended tilt. It is a freestanding bell tower of the cathedral in Pisa, Italy.
The Louvre Museum in Paris is the world’s largest art museum. It houses thousands of works including the Mona Lisa and the Venus de Milo.
Angkor Wat is a massive temple complex in Cambodia. Originally a Hindu temple, it later became a Buddhist site.
Petra is a historical and archaeological city in southern Jordan. It is famous for its rock-cut architecture and water conduit system.
The Parthenon is a former temple on the Athenian Acropolis dedicated to the goddess Athena. It exemplifies ancient Greek architecture.
Stonehenge is a prehistoric monument in England consisting of a ring of standing stones. Its purpose remains a subject of debate.
The Empire State Building is a 102-story skyscraper in New York City. It was the tallest building in the world when it was completed in 1931.
Mount Rushmore features the faces of four U.S. presidents carved into a granite mountain in South Dakota.
Neuschwanstein Castle is a 19th-century Romanesque Revival palace in Germany. It served as the inspiration for Disneyland’s Sleeping Beauty Castle.
The Forbidden City is a palace complex in Beijing, China. It was the home of emperors and their households for nearly 500 years.
Chichen Itza is a large pre-Columbian archaeological site in Mexico. It was a major city of the Maya civilization.
question: Where is the Eiffel Tower located?
answer: It is located in Paris, France.

documents: Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius under standard atmospheric pressure. Boiling is the process where a liquid turns into vapor when heated. This occurs when vapor pressure equals atmospheric pressure.
Freezing is the process where a liquid becomes a solid when cooled below its freezing point. For water, this occurs at 0 degrees Celsius.
Evaporation is the process by which molecules in a liquid state gain enough energy to enter the gaseous phase. It occurs at the surface of the liquid and can happen below the boiling point.
Condensation is the process where gas turns into a liquid. This commonly occurs when warm, moist air comes into contact with a cool surface.
Sublimation is the transition from a solid to gas without passing through a liquid phase. Dry ice, or solid carbon dioxide, is a common example.
Deposition is the phase transition in which gas turns directly into a solid, such as frost formation on a cold surface.
Melting is the process by which a solid becomes a liquid when heated above its melting point.
The specific heat capacity of water is high, meaning it requires a lot of energy to change temperature. This helps regulate Earth’s climate.
Steam is the gas phase of water that forms when water boils. It can be used to power turbines in electricity generation.
Humidity is the amount of water vapor present in the air. High humidity levels can make the air feel warmer.
Precipitation occurs when water droplets in clouds combine and become heavy enough to fall to Earth. It can fall as rain, snow, sleet, or hail.
The water cycle includes processes like evaporation, condensation, precipitation, and runoff. It moves water through Earth’s systems.
Clouds form when water vapor condenses into tiny droplets. They are classified by altitude and appearance.
Fog is a type of low-lying cloud formed when air near the ground cools to its dew point.
Dew forms when moisture from the air condenses on cool surfaces during the night. It’s commonly seen on grass in the morning.
A kettle uses a heating element to raise the water temperature until it boils. The escaping steam is often used as an indicator.
Boiling water produces bubbles that rise to the surface and burst, releasing vapor. The rate of boiling depends on heat applied and air pressure.
Pressure cookers raise the boiling point of water, cooking food faster. They operate by trapping steam and increasing internal pressure.
High-altitude areas experience lower boiling points for water. At Mount Everest’s summit, water boils at around 70 degrees Celsius.
A thermometer can measure the temperature of boiling water, typically showing 100°C at sea level.
question: At what temperature does water boil under standard atmospheric pressure?
answer: Water boils at 100 degrees Celsius under standard pressure.

documents: The human heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles. It pumps oxygenated blood to the body and deoxygenated blood to the lungs. The average adult heart beats about 100,000 times a day.
The lungs are responsible for exchanging oxygen and carbon dioxide with the blood. They are located in the chest cavity and are protected by the ribcage.
The brain is the control center of the nervous system. It processes sensory information and coordinates movement and behavior.
The liver is a vital organ involved in detoxification, protein synthesis, and digestion. It produces bile to aid in fat breakdown.
The kidneys filter blood to remove waste and excess fluid, producing urine. They also help regulate blood pressure and electrolyte balance.
The stomach secretes acid and enzymes to break down food. It churns food into a semi-liquid called chyme.
The intestines absorb nutrients from food and transport waste toward excretion. The small intestine is where most absorption occurs.
Bones provide structure to the body and protect internal organs. They also produce blood cells in the bone marrow.
Muscles contract to produce movement. They are connected to bones by tendons and controlled by the nervous system.
The skin is the body’s largest organ and acts as a barrier against pathogens. It helps regulate temperature and enables the sense of touch.
The pancreas produces insulin and digestive enzymes. It plays a crucial role in glucose metabolism.
The spleen filters blood and helps fight infection. It stores white blood cells and platelets.
The bladder stores urine before it is expelled from the body. It expands as it fills and signals the brain when it needs to be emptied.
The esophagus is a muscular tube that connects the throat to the stomach. It transports food via peristaltic motion.
The thyroid gland produces hormones that regulate metabolism, heart rate, and body temperature.
The gallbladder stores bile produced by the liver. It releases bile into the small intestine during digestion.
The diaphragm is a muscle that helps control breathing. It contracts and flattens when you inhale.
The immune system defends the body against infectious organisms. It includes white blood cells, lymph nodes, and antibodies.
The reproductive system enables humans to produce offspring. It includes organs such as the ovaries, testes, and uterus.
The circulatory system includes the heart, blood, and blood vessels. It delivers oxygen and nutrients throughout the body.
question: How many chambers does the human heart have?
answer: The human heart has four chambers.
